column7: 会社は 1985 年に創業されました。
column8: The company was established in 1985.
column9: kaisha wa 1985 nen ni sougyou saremashita.
column10: Used for starting a business or foundation.

column7: 彼の知名度は急上昇した。
column8: His reputation quickly rose.
column9: kare no chimeido wa kyuu joushou shita.
column10: Refers to how well-known someone or something is.

column7: 折り入ってお願いがあります。
column8: I have a request to make, urgently.
column9: oriitte onegai ga arimasu.
column10: Often used when making a serious request.

column7: 彼女のエレガンスには圧倒される。
column8: Her elegance is overwhelming.
column9: kanojo no eregansu ni wa attou sareru.
column10: Borrowed word from English, used to describe refined beauty or grace.

column5: to terminate, to reach an extreme
column7: その状況は極まった。
column8: The situation reached its extreme.
column9: sono joukyou wa kiwamatta.
column10: Can describe something reaching its limit or extreme state.

column7: 優美な舞踏が観客を魅了した。
column8: The graceful dance captivated the audience.
column9: yuubi na butou ga kankyaku o miryoushita.
column10: Often used for artistic or graceful movements.

column7: その映画のキャッチコピーは印象的だった。
column8: The movie's catchphrase was impressive.
column9: sono eiga no kyacchi kopii wa inshouteki datta.
column10: Borrowed from English, refers to a memorable phrase used for marketing.

column7: この道は曲線が多い。
column8: This road has many curves.
column9: kono michi wa kyokusen ga ooi.
column10: Describes the shape of something curving.

column5: effect, influence, to evoke a response
column7: その発言には大きな反響があった。
column8: The statement had a large impact.
column9: sono hatsugen ni wa ookina hankyou ga atta.
column10: Refers to the ripple effect or reaction to an event.

column7: 失敗したことに痛恨の極みを感じる。
column8: I feel deep regret for the mistake.
column9: shippai shita koto ni tsuukon no kiwami o kanjiru.
column10: Used for feelings of deep sorrow or regret.

column7: 彼は仕事の疲労を感じている。
column8: He is feeling the fatigue from work.
column9: kare wa shigoto no hirou o kanjiteiru.
column10: Describes a state of physical or mental exhaustion.

column7: この結果には遺憾の意を表する。
column8: I express regret for this result.
column9: kono kekka ni wa ikan no i o hyousuru.
column10: Describes dissatisfaction or regret in formal situations.

column7: それは物種から始まった。
column8: It started from the fundamental element.
column9: sore wa monodane kara hajimatta.
column10: Refers to something fundamental or basic from which something grows.

column7: 彼は赤面して恥ずかしそうだった。
column8: He was blushing and looked embarrassed.
column9: kare wa sekimen shite hazukashisou datta.
column10: Refers to the physical act of blushing, often from embarrassment.

column7: 彼は呑気に過ごしている。
column8: He is living carelessly.
column9: kare wa nonki ni sugoshiteiru.
column10: Can have a negative connotation, implying carelessness.

column7: あなたとお会いできて光栄です。
column8: It is an honor to meet you.
column9: anata to oai dekite kouei desu.
column10: Refers to a sense of pride or honor in an event.

column7: 彼はその賞に値する。
column8: He deserves that award.
column9: kare wa sono shou ni ataisuru.
column10: Used to indicate worthiness or merit for something.

column7: 彼は汗顔の思いで謝罪した。
column8: He apologized with deep shame.
column9: kare wa kangan no omoi de shazai shita.
column10: Refers to being ashamed to the point of sweating or embarrassment.

column7: 美術館で絵画を鑑賞した。
column8: I appreciated the paintings in the art gallery.
column9: bijutsukan de kaiga o kanshou shita.
column10: Commonly used in the context of art or culture.

column7: 彼は私の話に傾聴してくれた。
column8: He listened to my story attentively.
column9: kare wa watashi no hanashi ni keichou shite kureta.
column10: Implies deep or respectful listening.

column7: 念には念を入れた方がいい。
column8: It's better to be cautious.
column9: nen ni wa nen o iretahou ga ii.
column10: Refers to thoughts, wishes, or feelings of intent.

column7: このプロジェクトは皮切りに成功した。
column8: This project started successfully.
column9: kono purojekuto wa kawakiri ni seikou shita.
column10: Refers to the starting point or the beginning of an event.

column7: 彼は学級委員に選ばれた。
column8: He was chosen as the class representative.
column9: kare wa gakyuuiin ni erabareta.
column10: Refers to a student leader or class officer.

column7: 面白いエピソードを聞いた。
column8: I heard an interesting anecdote.
column9: omoshiroi episoodo o kiita.
column10: Borrowed from English, refers to a short story or event.

column5: to embezzle, to accustom oneself to using
column7: 彼は会社のお金を使い込んだ。
column8: He embezzled company funds.
column9: kare wa kaisha no okane o tsukaikonda.
column10: Can refer to both using something long-term and misappropriating funds.

column7: 彼はその州の知事を務めている。
column8: He serves as the governor of the state.
column9: kare wa sono shuu no chiji o tsutometeiru.
column10: The official title for a state or prefectural governor in Japan.

column7: この会議は公費で開催された。
column8: This meeting was held at public expense.
column9: kono kaigi wa kouhi de kaisai sareta.
column10: Refers to government or taxpayer funds used for official purposes.

column7: 旅行の費用は私費で支払った。
column8: The travel expenses were paid out of personal funds.
column9: ryokou no hiyou wa shihi de shiharatta.
column10: Refers to expenses paid privately, not with public or company funds.

column5: recoil, shrink, flinch, cringe, be annoyed
column7: 彼の態度には辟易した。
column8: I was disgusted by his attitude.
column9: kare no taido ni wa hekieki shita.
column10: Refers to a strong reaction of distaste or discomfort.

column7: そのレストランは繁盛している。
column8: The restaurant is thriving.
column9: sono resutoran wa hanjou shiteiru.
column10: Describes something that is flourishing or prosperous, often used for businesses.

column7: 彼は書類を改ざんした。
column8: He falsified the documents.
column9: kare wa shorui o kaizan shita.
column10: Refers to the act of altering or falsifying information or documents.

column7: 議会では激しい討論が行われた。
column8: Intense debates took place in the legislature.
column9: gikai de wa hageshii touron ga okonawareta.
column10: Refers to formal discussions or debates, often in a public setting.

column7: 彼のビジネスは若者の顧客層をターゲットにしている。
column8: His business targets a young customer base.
column9: kare no bijinesu wa wakamono no kokyaku sou o taagetto ni shiteiru.
column10: Refers to the demographic or group of customers that a business serves.

column7: そのブランドは最新のトレンドを追っている。
column8: The brand is following the latest trends.
column9: sono burando wa saishin no torendo o otteiru.
column10: Borrowed from English, used for the latest styles or trends in fashion, technology, etc.

column7: 彼の本性は素晴らしい人だった。
column8: His true character was that of a wonderful person.
column9: kare no honshou wa subarashii hito datta.
column10: Refers to someone's inherent nature or personality.

column5: to provide, to prepare, to lay down
column7: 彼は新しい規則を設けた。
column8: He set new rules.
column9: kare wa atarashii kisoku o mouketa.
column10: Refers to establishing or preparing something, such as rules or systems.

column7: それは正当な理由です。
column8: That is a legitimate reason.
column9: sore wa seitou na riyuu desu.
column10: Describes something that is fair, justified, or appropriate.

column7: 彼の態度は酷すぎる。
column8: His attitude is too severe.
column9: kare no taido wa kokusugiru.
column10: Often used to describe something that is harsh or extremely negative.

column7: 彼は徹夜して仕事を終わらせた。
column8: He stayed up all night to finish his work.
column9: kare wa tetsuya shite shigoto o owaraseta.
column10: Refers to staying awake the entire night to complete tasks.

column7: 台所の戸棚には食器が入っている。
column8: The cupboard in the kitchen contains dishes.
column9: daidokoro no todana ni wa shokki ga haitteiru.
column10: Used for storage furniture, like cabinets or shelves.

column7: 長時間歩いて、ふらふらしている。
column8: After walking for hours, I feel dizzy.
column9: choujikan aruite, furafura shiteiru.
column10: Describes a feeling of being dizzy or exhausted, often from fatigue.

column7: 彼は無敵の選手だ。
column8: He is an invincible player.
column9: kare wa muteki no senshu da.
column10: Refers to someone or something unbeatable or without rival.

column7: それは彼の無実を証明する証拠だ。
column8: That is proof of his innocence.
column9: sore wa kare no mujitsu o shoumei suru shouko da.
column10: Refers to something that proves a fact or argument.

column7: これは当たり前のことだ。
column8: This is a common thing.
column9: kore wa atarimae no koto da.
column10: Refers to something that is obvious or natural in a given situation.

column7: 他人の意見を尊重すべきだ。
column8: You should respect other people's opinions.
column9: tanin no iken o sonchou subeki da.
column10: Refers to people who are not yourself, can be strangers or others.

column7: 音楽のジャンルは多様だ。
column8: There are many genres of music.
column9: ongaku no janru wa tayou da.
column10: Borrowed from English, used for categories or types of things.

column7: いろいろな種類の果物が売られている。
column8: Various kinds of fruit are being sold.
column9: iroirona shurui no kudamono ga urareteiru.
column10: Refers to different types or categories of things.

column7: 日本語には尊敬語が多い。
column8: Japanese has many honorific expressions.
column9: nihongo ni wa sonkeigo ga ooi.
column10: A form of polite language used to show respect to others.

column7: 彼は謙譲語をよく使う。
column8: He often uses humble expressions.
column9: kare wa kenjougo o yoku tsukau.
column10: A form of polite language where the speaker humbly lowers themselves.

column7: 丁寧語は日本語の基本だ。
column8: Polite expressions are the basics of Japanese.
column9: teineigo wa nihongo no kihon da.
column10: A general term for the formal, polite language in Japanese.

column7: その瞬時に彼の目が輝いた。
column8: In that moment, his eyes sparkled.
column9: sono shunji ni kare no me ga kagayaita.
column10: Refers to a very brief, instantaneous period of time.

column5: to change, to switch over, to replace
column7: 私は新しい仕事に切り替えた。
column8: I switched to a new job.
column9: watashi wa atarashii shigoto ni kirikaeta.
column10: Refers to changing or switching between states or things.

column7: この言葉の誤用は避けるべきだ。
column8: The misuse of this word should be avoided.
column9: kono kotoba no goyou wa sakeru beki da.
column10: Refers to the incorrect or inappropriate use of something.

column7: 手紙を書くために便箋を買った。
column8: I bought letter paper to write a letter.
column9: tegami o kaku tame ni binsen o katta.
column10: Refers to paper used for writing letters.

column5: to spell, to write, to compose
column7: 彼は日記を綴るのが好きだ。
column8: He likes to write in his diary.
column9: kare wa nikki o tsuzuru no ga suki da.
column10: Refers to writing or composing, often used for diaries or stories.

column7: それは彼の宿命だった。
column8: That was his fate.
column9: sore wa kare no shukumei datta.
column10: Refers to a predestined fate or destiny that cannot be avoided.

column7: このソフトウェアの仕様はまだ決まっていない。
column8: The specifications for this software have not been decided yet.
column9: kono sofutouea no shiyou wa mada kimatte inai.
column10: Refers to the specifications or method of doing something.

column7: 彼の話を聞いて、ぐっと心が動いた。
column8: After listening to his story, my heart was deeply moved.
column9: kare no hanashi o kiite, gutto kokoro ga ugoita.
column10: Expresses a sudden or significant change in action, emotion, or effect.

column7: その計画は特定の前提に基づいている。
column8: The plan is based on a specific premise.
column9: sono keikaku wa tokutei no zentei ni motozuiteiru.
column10: Refers to the underlying assumption or condition for something.

column7: 完璧なタイミングで登場した。
column8: He appeared at the perfect timing.
column9: kanpeki na taimingude toujou shita.
column10: Borrowed from English, refers to the right moment or timing for an action.

column7: 彼は未だにその問題を解決していない。
column8: He still hasn't solved that problem.
column9: kare wa imada ni sono mondai o kaiketsu shiteinai.
column10: Used to indicate something that has not happened yet or is still in progress.

column5: to look downward, to cast one's eyes down
column7: 彼は恥ずかしそうに俯いた。
column8: He looked down in embarrassment.
column9: kare wa hazukashisou ni utsumuita.
column10: Refers to physically lowering one's head or gaze, often due to shyness or shame.

column7: ちょくちょく彼の家に遊びに行く。
column8: I often visit his house.
column9: chokuchoku kare no ie ni asobi ni iku.
column10: Refers to doing something regularly or frequently.

column7: てんでダメだった。
column8: It was completely useless.
column9: tende dame datta.
column10: Expresses something that is completely or utterly in a negative state.

column7: 彼の意見に同感だ。
column8: I agree with his opinion.
column9: kare no iken ni doukan da.
column10: Refers to agreeing with someone's feelings or opinions.

column7: 彼は馴れ馴れしい態度を取る。
column8: He acts too familiar.
column9: kare wa narenare-shii taido o toru.
column10: Describes someone who is excessively informal or overly friendly in an inappropriate manner.

column5: to escape from, to run away
column7: 彼は家を逃げ出した。
column8: He ran away from home.
column9: kare wa ie o nigedashita.
column10: Refers to physically escaping from a place or situation.

column5: to coax, to beg, to plead for
column7: 子供はお菓子をねだる。
column8: The child begs for candy.
column9: kodomo wa okashi o nedaru.
column10: Refers to asking for something persistently or pleading.

column5: to look forward to, to wait impatiently
column7: その映画の公開が待ち遠しい。
column8: I can't wait for the movie to be released.
column9: sono eiga no koukai ga machidooshii.
column10: Expresses eager anticipation or impatience for something to happen.

column5: crowd, mass, to close up together
column7: 密集した人々が集まっていた。
column8: A crowd of people had gathered.
column9: misshuu shita hitobito ga atsumatte ita.
column10: Refers to things or people packed closely together in a dense group.

column7: もはや手遅れだ。
column8: It's already too late.
column9: mohiya teokure da.
column10: Refers to something that has already occurred or is now impossible.

column7: 役場で申請書を提出した。
column8: I submitted the application form at the town hall.
column9: yakuba de shinseisho o teishutsu shita.
column10: Refers to the administrative office or government building of a town or village.

column7: 彼の家は大きな屋敷だ。
column8: His house is a large mansion.
column9: kare no ie wa ookina yashiki da.
column10: Refers to a large, often traditional, house or estate.
